newsitem.title: JAPAN: Mazda sees new station wagon luring young drivers.
newsitem.headline: Mazda sees new station wagon luring young drivers.

text.p: Japanese carmaker Mazda, as part of a struggle to drag itself out of a slump, on Monday launched a stylish station wagon at a comparatively low price to lure young customers away from its bigger rivals.
The Demio, geared to young families, resembles a mini-van and is powered by a 1.3 or 1.5-litre engine.
It was launched amid fanfare attended by Mazda's new president, Henry Wallace, who is the first foreigner to head a major Japanese company.
"The Demio is flexible, fun to drive, easy to drive in the city but roomy, and great value," Wallace told Japanese reporters at a press preview.
Wallace's celebrity status in Japan was marked by Mazda's decision to feature him in full-page advertisements in Japanese newspapers last week.

The Demio will be priced from below 800,000 yen ($7,407), Wallace said. The domestic price will start at 798,000 yen ($7,388) for the 1.3-litre model with a five-speed manual gearbox and no air-conditioner.

The cheapest car on the domestic market with a 1.3-litre engine is not a recreational vehicle but Toyota Motor's Starlet three-door hatchback with a price tag of 730,000 yen ($6,759) without an air conditioner.
Other makers have an array of recreational vehicles and Mazda itself also has several recreational vehicles such as the Bongo Friendee camper, MPV minivan, and Capella station wagon.
But Mazda maintains that none quite matches the shape and style of the Demio. It said the vehicle's name is derived from the Spanish "de mio" meaning "mine".
Daihatsu Motor, an affiliate of Toyota, is due to launch on August 28 the 1.5-litre Pyzer recreational vehicle, which is slightly bigger than the Demio.
The Demio is equipped with driver's side air bag and anti-lock brake system as standard.
"The sales target for the Demio is 4,000 a month. However, for initial sales, we are planning 5,000," Wallace said.
Wallace said Mazda aims to provide a higher degree of customer satisfaction, which the Demio will provide. This is the top priority, he said.
"The Demio, which is introduced today, is the very first example of the new Mazda corporate direction," Wallace said.
He said sales were weaker than planned, but overall the company was still comfortable with the full-year projection because of the weaker yen.
"We are still projecting net profit of 20 billion yen ($185 million), unchanged (from an earlier estimate)."

Mazda posted net profit of just 300 million yen ($2.7 million) in the last business year after posting a net loss of 35.70 billion yen ($330 million) the year before. In May, Mazda had forecast parent net profit of 20 billion yen ($185 million) in this business year.

Mazda plans to start exporting the new Demio in October at a rate of 500 per month to Australia and other Asian countries. It will not introduce the model in the United States because it is not a compact-vehicle market, Wallace said.

Nikko Research analyst Tsunemi Tachibana said: "Sales of the Demio are likely to be tough because several makers are expected to launch similar models. The weak point of the Demio is that it has no four-wheel-drive version." ($1=108 yen)
